Award.AbstractNarration:
This project plans to provide policy-driven data management for distributed collections. The technology developed through this effort supports data virtualization, affording a global view and controlled management and sharing of distributed data, across heterogeneous and cloud resources. As a data grid, it provides abstractions for data objects, resources, and users and manages access to underlying physical infrastructure. This technology also abstracts data management, separating policy implementation from physical storage; the technology's rules allow data managers to automate administrative services and to implement policies for replication, distribution, pre- and post-processing, metadata management, etc. - independently of the (local or remote) data storage system. This technology can be used for managing data distributed across the cloud.

Scientific data collections represent intellectual capital from which future research and evidence-based decisions can be derived. As collections grow, demand increases for data sharing, data publication, and data preservation; these are all necessary to enable data-based scientific advancement when data volume is high and analysis is sophisticated. The technology developed through this project has already proven itself in scientific data management; it is widely used within national research projects and around the world in institutions whose crushing data needs compel them to seek new infrastructure technologies. The proposed project hopes to facilitate the build-out of custom environments and new deployments that implement complex data policy.

This proposal is synergistic with many innovative business opportunities that will leverage big data. Harnessing opportunities and creating value for businesses, scientists, and government requires storing, managing, and analyzing high volumes and wide varieties of data. This project provides technology for doing that.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The I-Corps Data Grid Services project purpose was to explore a market-based support and services business model, based on the open-source software developed and supported by our groups, the Data Intensive Cyber Environments group (DICE) and the Renaissance Computing Institute (RENCI) at the University of North Carolina Chapel Hill.  Our continuing goal is the promotion of the technology transfer of our data management middleware, currently used in research institutions and government agencies worldwide to automate data operations and implement data strategies. Our exploration of the potential for data management in industry was enabled by the NSF I-Corps program, which allowed us to carry out crucial market studies and investigate industry demand for data services such as ours.

Intellectual Merit. Data management is an overloaded term, ill-defined even among data professionals. As part of the market research for this project, we set the term aside and spoke with industry representatives about their own data issues—and what they do to address the challenges. This yielded valuable information about industry response to Big Data. While very big companies are ready to invest in the promise of sophisticated data infrastructure, some sectors are simply overwhelmed by the implication that Big Data requires Big Investment in Big Disruptive Infrastructure. The reality is that important data support functionalities can often be supplied by incremental modification to existing infrastructure. We have identified the misperception—that “data management” implies gargantuan investment and a total overhaul of infrastructure—and can now contribute to correcting it. Throwing off this mistaken perception should help enterprises get more value from their data and from their infrastructure investments.

Broad Impact. The rapprochement of academic research and industry enables partnerships that benefit both academics and industry pacesetters. Where this touches on Big Data, the benefits may be even farther reaching; given the state of existing academic technology, it is enough to know actual market demand in order to guide development to deliver a middleware tool that simplifies the management of data operations, enabling small and large businesses alike to handle data well—for preservation or for analysis. 

As a result of this project we have determined a path forward for diversifying our funding base and serving as a first step in the technology transfer; we have launched a consortium, whose membership fees support our development efforts and contribute to the sustainability of the project. The same fees allow members to protect their investment in our technology, influence the roadmap of the open-source software, and access our support services. This will supplement the research funding we have traditionally depended on to finance our software development.

Thanks to the market research enabled by this project, we have also been able to identify and understand several factors that should help us target future “customers” of the open-source software or of our services. Such understanding should help us to grow the consortium and succeed at transferring our technology from academia to commercial markets. These factors include the following:
